author: @gargeeghosh3912
text: To help you improve: Decrease the angle theta by which the car turns when sees an object, theta should be more than diameter of the object. Speed control where speed=x, x depends on closeness of an object. Slowing down x(speed) on turns or angles which are higher than 50 degree and speed x is max at theta is=0 to theta = 10 degrees and object distance is equivalent of 50 m away(units as u wish)  Activating horn where distance=d is less than equal to 10m  I provided you with the physics and programming is on you and as a fellow coder these improvements will not take a lot of time but will make the ride a lot more smoother!

author: @alexanderreusens7633
text: First-timer here, did you just gave Charles the data to train on and let it learn how to drive completely by itself, or have you done a more modular approach and guided him through the learning?  For instance, first learning to read directions, by predicting where the car would go while you drive on empty streets.  Then learning to avoid cars and obstacles by predicting your inputs while again, watching you drive, this time busy roads, and only then letting it drive by itself?  If not, would this guided learning be expected to give better results, or is it simply not worth the extra effort?

author: @MephistoDerPudel
text: Mhh, some ideas:  1. Make it recurrent, so he knows, what he did in the moment before. Especially when he's stuck, this could lead to a difference. 2. Give him an option to don't press any key. So he can control the speed.  I think for training a real good AI, you would need more Informations and a Model, thats more flexible. Think evolutionary models would be nice, with crashes, driving on the wrong side of the road, running red lights,  going tom much over the speed limit as game-over points for getting into the next iteration.  Another idea could be, to use a GAN-like structure, one with the bot and another input taken from the perspective of a cab, or so.

author: @Nedko066
text: Hey, cool project!  Sorry if I'm telling you stuff you already know but also data centering is important - normalizing the pixels between 0 and 1 is not enough. Normally this is done by finding a mean image, normalizing it between 0 and 1, subtract it from the normalized input image. This will center your data distribution to 0, which is important for training. You could try using the mean image from ImageNet but in your case it is probably best if you compute it yourself from a lot of samples.

text: hmmmm, for when it gets stuck, maybe you could set up a way to record training data while you pause to correct it. author: @manpance555
text: Have you tried integrating data collection with the driving?  What I mean by that is, if it drives itself into a position where it gets stuck, you take control and record correcting the problem.  You mentioned that you already had some data on reversing away from trees/walls, but maybe if you tailor the data to the specific instances it gets stuck in it will be more effective.

author: @Hobbitstomper
text: Looking on what leads up to most accidents, it seems that Charles is simply speeding too fast. I know on the PC we only have one speed by pressing W and then letting go to slow down. On the controller however, it's more realistic, as you can hold down the trigger button and depending on how much you hold down (0% - 100%), it will have a different constant speed. Maybe making Charles simulate the trigger button of a controller, to use it at 50% - 70%, will make him drive slower and steadier, which will cause less accidents.

author: @rudemanthony
text: Should teach Charles how to use analog inputs for acceleration and braking, instead of W and S. Charles could be made to cruise at a constant speed, as opposed to putting the pedal to the metal. Of course you'd probably have to train an acceleration model as well... with as many points as you want to break up the the range of the acceleration/braking inputs.

author: @resonance999
text: This method is hitting the most known bumps in imitation learning (which is what the general method sentex is using is called). Specifically, if the car deviates from doing the right thing a little bit (strays from the lane), it won't know what to do next, because most of the examples in the data set are of staying neatly on lane, and this error compounds.  One known solution is to train the model to rectify itself so it doesn't reach unknown territory (driving off road).  A common way of doing this is to add  two cameras slightly  tilted to the sides to simulate a situation where the car is veering off. The left camera's images should be labeled to turn right and vice versa. Of course, this  solution might be difficult to implement in gta v. Another approach is data aggregation (DAgger), where after training the model is let out into the wild to do it's own thing and start making mistakes. As it gets into these new situations,  the observations (video frames) should be recorded and a human will manually label them with the right course of action. Then the model is retrained with the old data + new data, and the process is repeated until the model performs well. Sentex's thought of having data about what to do when you hit a tree does much the same thing. The other suggestions for improving the model are general improvements, but won't fix the underlying problems of this learning method and are unlikely to yield much improvement.  Thanks for sharing your thoughts, sentex, keep up the good work!

author: @hansen1101
text: thanks for your update on the gta series. it really is an impressive project. maybe rnn could help boosting the performance in situations where the agents gets stuck. ;) could you please provide some details on how the additional set of weights are applied to the output layer? i could not find any information about that step in your 'python plays gta v' series (or probably must have overseen it) and want to make sure that i get it right. 1. are the set of manual weights applied a) before the last dense layer (as a replacement of the last slice of learned weights) or b) after the last dense layer but before a final softmax activation layer in order to balance the output distribution. 2. if you applied method b): is the length of the last weights vector simply equal to the size of the prediction set Y (i.e. one weight per class)? or are there some other linear combinations/dependencies in place? 3. regarding the 'closeness score': did you introduce a new loss function (or adjust the loss function) to the model, such that the different distances between predictions and ground truth are considered?

author: @JoshTechBytes
text: I'd imagine the in-game performance and training time would take a hit if you tried this, but have you considered trying to add some sort of depth perception? I.e. distance from objects etc. Perhaps a mod that adds stereoscopic 3D or VR, and thus a seperate image for each eye would allow calculation of distance, and thus mimic advanced sensors on actual self driving vehicles. I'd imagine that it would be easier for the network to determine whether it should reverse from poles, who knows, could be interesting! Anyway, great job thus far, much better than the last time I saw it on twitch. Keep it up :).
